reviewText:
Considering it’s a fan made product and seeing how much they worked on it, this game is awesome! It has some flaws but still catches the Painkiller feeling even from the another view of a new bizzare but cool protagonist. A perfect descendant of the original.

Pros:
- Everything that was good in the original presented here as well. Level design, enemies weapons, sounds, athmosphere.
- Graphics. They worked on this one very very hard and i say well done! Nearly everything has been redesigned to fit the new protagonist. Perfect!
- Weapons. Old weapons with new look and minor new capabilities! The new weapons. . .Your first weapon (besides the redesigned cube) is a head of your gaoler. Most people notice it’s a cool laser shooter but the real fun starts with it’s alternate fire. It shouts on your enemies with a really scary-good sound effect, causing most basic enemies’ heart stopping (aren’t they dead already? oh well. . .) and insta-kill them into a shaking, painfull death. What a truly satisfying weapon! I could do that all day! And the new living grenade. . .
- Cool new enemies. Oh Geishas. . .hehe!

Cons:
- Even more unbalanced enemies than in the original, more insta-killers on normal difficulty. The gang members and the flamethrowers (especially the miniboss) caused me practise violent vulgarisms but also made me stand up and relax a few mins so it was nearly healthy.

8/10 – Fun oldskool FPS

(Sorry for my English!)

reviewText:
TL;DR  Game is good and balanced, if not appealing to everyone

First of all, Painkiller: Black Edition is almost universally accepted as the better game. If you're gonna choose only one, get the original (also on steam).

The rest of this review is the BS people are complaining about.

Now to the people complaining about difficulty, weapons, etc. Yes the weapons are a little weak, but you get so much ammo and all of the enemies can be lead like sheep. You can hold every weapon at once and always have the melee/death-ray cube thing with unlimited ammo (its ♥♥♥♥ing strong too), so if you have ammo issues, your aim is abysmal. Really abysmal.

As for the difficulty: Enemies with melee attacks are strong because they should never catch up to you. Seriously, you can bunny hop more than twice as fast as they walk. You even slide up and over enemies when you jump.. Even when you do get hit it takes at least 10 hits to kill you from the standard 100 HP (max HP is something between 150-250, I've never really paid attention) PLUS armour.. And if you still can't handle the enemies, there's a difficulty setting for a reason.

The load times are fine. The one guy saying the times are 10+ minutes must have a hamster instead of a processor. The load times are a little longer than most, but theyre fine.

Enemy variants are plentiful (new enemies every level so far).

Overall there are 17 levels, 20 minutes or more each. Even rushing through the game, you get 5+ hours of gameplay.

Recomended (but Painkiller: Black beats Overdoes)

reviewText:
The game has some beautiful level aesthetics and monster designs, which is almost a shame, because everything about the actual gameplay is so bad that these great assets are just wasted.

Even on normal difficulty, you'll find yourself running out of ammo for not just your favorite weapon, but for all half dozen separate weapons extremely frequently - including secondary ammo!  You are simply not given enough bullets to work with, turning what should be tense or exciting fights against dozens of enemies into pure frustration as you run around looking for what few ammo pickups have been hidden across the large expanses.

While being forced to make the best of it with your infinite ammo starter weapon, you'll have to slog your way through countless bullet spongey enemies, many of which spawn adjacent to you, teleport or use incredibly hard to see projectiles.  Unfortunately, your character, who seems defined primarily by his ability to recycle the same three or four unpleasantly dull one liners throughout the whole game, is not nearly tanky enough to deal with these battles very well.

Finally, even the weapons are merely recycled clones of Painkiller Black's arsenal, making them not so much new as modded.

The not too shabby presentation of this game is let down by almost everything else about it, but especially by the total lack of respect for the player given in the design of enemy encounters.  Mixing and matching the strict ammo rationing of a Silent Hill game with the relentless hordes of a Serious Sam makes for a poor FPS experience, whether you're oldschool or new school.

reviewText: A rather unbalanced experience, not enough good weapons and ammo to do battle with some very powerful enemies whom spawn in the most inconvenient areas and en masse without any restraint.  Even the hardest levels in the original Painkiller and Battle out of Hell had a steady and reasonable of enemies, it also knew which enemies to have en masse.  This game doesn't.  After this experience I feel like overdosing on the painkillers in my medicine cabinet.
voteText: 37 of 63 people (59%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
AUDIO:
Various styles ranging from heavy metal, carnival music, and spooky haunted house style stuff that fits the level that you are in. There is a lot of variety here and it's nice to have so many different songs to kill baddies to. Belial is a one-liner spewing jerk throughout the game. It's nice to hear him comment at the beginning of every level because it can be humorous and it gives him personality, but good lord he never shuts up while you're playing. I LOVE THE TASTE OF EVIL SOULS IN THE MORNING.

VISUALS:
Like the original Painkiller, Overdose offers a plethora of different environments to gib enemies in. A snowy viking village, the battlefields of the American Civil War, and a movie studio production lot to name a few. Every level is drastically different in theme from the previous one, so it offers a good incentive to keep going and see just how diverse this game can get. The enemies change every level to match the setting, so you won't really run into them multiple times except in a level near the end.

PLAYABLILITY:
This game does have a tendency to get hair-rippingly difficult at times. Mainly when they pit you against a horde of enemies that have some sort of quirk that melts your health to nothing in no time flat in a claustrophobic environment. Like the Riot level. Those flamethrower enemies are ridiculous. Aside from that little balancing issue, it is the same frantic and fast paced gameplay as the original Painkiller.

DELIVERY:
The gameplay is very similar to the Serious Sam line of games, just set to a darker tone. There is a pretty large variety of weapons to choose from; some a bit more useful than others. If you've played the original Painkiller, they're basically just reskins of those weapons. Each level offers you a challenge to complete in order to unlock Cards which can be used to grant you special powers, such as faster speed or changing how much damage you do. Overdose is the type of game that focuses more on its gameplay than its story, with maybe 4 total cutscenes in the whole game that sum up the story to that point. Easy to understand and doesn't take itself very seriously.

SUMMARY:
So the big question is: Should you play this game? My answer to you is that you should go decide if you want to play Painkiller: Black Edition first. If you play through that and need more Painkiller to satiate your appetite, then give this a whirl. it's not as balanced or polished as Black Edition is, but it is still fun to give a playthrough. If you didn't like Black Edition, than you are sure as hell not going to like this one. It is a game with flaws, but it still pulls through in the end.

Final Score: 7/10

reviewText:
If you're looking for a challenging, fast paced old school FPS with cool weapons, tonnes of enemies to kill and a great art design, Painkiller Overdose is the game for you. There are lots of collectables to find along the way, rewarding players for exploring the maps. This keeps the pacing of the gameplay steady and allows you to take a few deep breaths after murdering countless demons and trust me, you'll need to. Enemy ai isn't the best but they will team up to ko you. Some enemies have tricks up their sleeve to be careful of. Plus there are many environmental hazards to look out for such as lava, swinging maces etc. There are also tarot cards to collect which give you special powers when activated once per level. These cards are permenant and you can unlock them by satisfying certain conditions at the end of a level. The weapons are cooler than ever, you will get some really creative ones to try as well as your conventional shotgun. Levels are well designed and have lots of hidden ammo/secrets and tonnes of enemies to kill.

Another thing to note is that the protagonist, Belial who just happeneds to be a demon/angel hybrid is a far more entertaining character than Daniel and has the tendancy to deliver one liners every now and again, particularly after consuming his favourite food, evil souls and he makes this very clear.

The only downsides are the framerate drop which often occurs when enemies spawn into the map. This can be annoying and can break you away from the action sometimes. Plus the enemy ai can be pretty stupid when it comes to pathing, something you'll find in most painkiller titles, enemies will lose track of you easily. Also be careful with your saves. always delete the ones you don't need as the game has the tendancy to corrupt data and crash the game when too many sames are accumilated. One level in particular, Animal Farm has an awful save glitch which can corrupt data randomly on that level, basically you're required to beat it all in one sitting with no deaths as i guarrentee 80% of the time, the checkpoint autosaves will get corrupted, if you want to get the tarot card on that level, i strongly reccommend playing it on daydream to save yourself the frustration of dying and having to return to the beginning of the level.

Other than that, this game is worth picking up if you are looking for a cheap old school shooter with a twist. Pick up the black edition too.

reviewText:
An unnecessary expansion pack to a great old-school FPS shooter developed 10 years ago. While the game was advertised as having new levels, weapons and enemy types I did not find many of these original. Simply put: Painkiller was not a new thing back in 2007. Other FPS games were announced / released and my attention was on them instead of the arrival of the 2nd expansion pack.

Also, Battle Out Of Hell was an exceptionally good expansion pack that was an appropriate finish to this franchise. But starting with Overdose a series of additional expansion packs were unleashed later on (follow-up games in order: Redemption, Resurrection, Recurring Evil) that tried to improve upon the original Painkiller experience but tried so desperately and so hard that eventually they ended up ruining this name.

Overdose was the first and the only that probably was not a failure in its entirety. It was just mediocre and made me realise the vanilla game along with its expansion were much, much better.
voteText: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I had a great time with Painkiller Overdose and I still play it to improve my scores and try higher difficulties.
I have tried Black Edition and I agree it's the better version, but this game has a quicker more arcade feel to it that I enjoy.

For those unfamiliar with this series, Painkiller is a fast paced arena style FPS (first person shooter), and I would compare it to Quake 3 in terms of controls and jumping.

There are 17 maps in 3 chapters (or so) with a couple bosses and tons of unique and creative enemies. You have a lot of weapons to use, and some hidden secrets and pickups in the maps. You will find some weapons work better on enemies than others as you play which is quite satisfying.
This game has great sound effects, great graphics, and lots of blood and gore.

Multiplayer is dead unless you add friends to play with and play via IP address. Gamespy ran the master servers but they have been taken down. You may encounter problems hosting if you are using a router.

Overdose is cheaper than Black Edition,  don't pass this one up, it's very fun.

reviewText:
Here is the jist of the game:

Go from point A to point B, kill everyone
Get a crazy awesome weapon
Go from point B to C, Kill everyone, run out of ammo
Use the crazy awesome starter weapon.
Go back from C to B, and kill everyone again
Win the Level
Go to a new level with an interesting new theme.
And you enjoy every minute of it.

Oh yeah and this naked chick stops by and talks to you once in a while, never really understood why. I think it was just lame story stuff.

column46: the stages are usually pretty huge
column47: and the game overall just looks like every metal video ever. Just the way it should be. Fortunately
column48: the weird screen shake glitch didn't happen like it did in the original. I still turned it off
column49: as it really was just more annoying than anything else. As for the technical side of things
column50: this game does require a bit of juice to get going
column51: but as long as you've got what the recommended card is on the Steam page
column52: you should be just fine. I didn't really experience any graphical glitches
column53: although there was some portions of 2-5 that caused a considerable amount of lag for no reason whatsoever. This was only a two or three minute stretch of the game
column54: so I'd consider it inconsequential. Overall
column55: this game still manages to hold the high standard that one would expect from Painkiller's graphical capabilities. It's definitely a game that'll still look pretty awesome in five or ten years time. 5/5.\n\nSound: This game has a real big issue with peak limiting. Like seriously
column56: it got so bad at times that I had to turn off the game audio
column57: as it was hurting my ears. I don't know why
column58: though. 3-5 was the biggest culprit of this issue
column60: the soundtrack is a bit... different this time around. Rather than going SO METAL
column61: the composer decided to branch out a little bit. In fact
column62: there really isn't any metal tracks in the game at all
column63: save for the one from the repeat level from BOoH (oh yeah
column64: did I mention this game lifts a level from BOoH?). While the change is nice
column65: it runs the risk of being forgettable and not necessarily conducive to what's going on in the game. And to be honest
column66: I really can't remember a single song from this game
column68: the songs may have gotten tired after a while
column69: but there's a lot of memorable riffs in there. It's not a soundtrack I'd get for myself. As for the voice acting
column70: again the main issue is the dialogue the one VA has to work with
column71: so it's a bit tricky for me to pass judgement on the quality of the VAs. However
column72: what I can pass judgement on are the audio engine and the soundtrack
column73: which are both honestly pretty disappointing. 2/5.\n\nOverall scores are: 7/5/5/2; cumulative score of 6.3/10. It's not something I'd see myself replaying too terribly often
column74: but I don't feel bad about spending my time playing it
column76: you might like this. You've probably already got the Painkiller Pack that goes on sale quite often
column77: so you might as well dive in. It's better than a lot of modern shooters

reviewText:
I can’t recommend it even though I like it. This game would be a ‘8.5/10’ for me, if it were not for three things.

First, the loading times. After being killed, re-loading takes almost 37 seconds, and you have to concentrate. If you start daydreaming the game loads and you’re not ready.

Second. The difficulty levels could use another level. There are four. I like to play about half difficulty, or just over. Here second level feels too easy, and gives you a full health at every checkpoint. Third level, is about right. It makes you feel you have to hammer the baddies. Only when it gets tough, and you start dying, then re-loading kills enthusiasm.

Thirdly, there are two nasty bugs in loading saved files. One is in the  level Dead Marsh, you have to play about three checkpoints without being able to load a saved file. The other is reported only in the Steam release of Painkiller in the level  Animal Farm. I finished the level before I saved to load, or quit. (Just in case.)

Otherwise, I quite love this game. Sadly though with all it faults 5/10 at best. I've played the three quarters of the game so far. The good parts are great though, like eerie wooden buildings, and levels in different places in time.

Also I could really use a game manual on this one. There are tarot cards, which you win and have bonus effects, and we need the info on them.

reviewText:
Here is the jist of the game:

Go from point A to point B, kill everyone
Get a crazy awesome weapon
Go from point B to C, Kill everyone, run out of ammo
Use the crazy awesome starter weapon.
Go back from C to B, and kill everyone again
Win the Level
Go to a new level with an interesting new theme.
And you enjoy every minute of it.

Oh yeah and this naked chick stops by and talks to you once in a while, never really understood why. I think it was just lame story stuff.

Broken game. Don't buy.

reviewText:
Mindware Studios foreshadow the sullen, depressing future of the Painkiller series with their clumsy and uninspired misfire of a sequel. Aside from a few aesthetically pleasing and well-designed levels/enemies, everything else falls flat. Unbalanced weapons, erratic difficulty spikes, atrocious boss battles and an aggressively unlikeable, annoying main character, mix together in a fetid cauldron to produce the hideous slime that is Painkiller Overdose. While the core gameplay still remains largely intact, it can't shine through the heavy layering of all the negative components.

It would be impossible to overdose on this pill, as it lacks any addictive qualities.

5/10

reviewText:
Ok, after a lot of poking around you CAN MAKE BELIAL SHUT THE HELL UP WITH THE ONE LINERS.  Only one way I found that works though.

http://pkzone.org/downloads/powermad-overdose/

Overlay called PowerMad for Overdose that lets you mess around with a lot of settings that the retail copy disabled for some who the heck knows why reason, as well as correcting a few of the weirder ammo placement/etc. bugs.

Check the instructions for using it with steam for how to do it after downloading and installing.  The ONLY way I actually got it work with Steam was by using the first 'rename powermad.pak into LScripts.pak' method.  Not the most elegant solution, but since the only thing it goofs up is online play who cares.  (Not like there are any servers for online play anyway it seems.)

Command to make him stop once you get it all installed and the game running is to hit tilde (the ~ key) and type pmtrashtalk.  (Relative) peace and quiet FTW.

Totally worth it to make the idiot shut his half-demon half-angel annoying GD mouth.

reviewText: This game blows. It oscilates between stupidly easy, and stupidly difficult. The monster design is not at all thought out like the previous games.  There are giant enemies who you shoot once with anything and they have to go into a 2 second yelp animation where they are completely helpless and basically stun-locked by any weapon you choose. Then there are several enemies who go invisible and then pop out of invisibility right next to you while doing damage.  This makes no sense. There is no tracking the enemy or countering this. They just do it and you have to hope you're beefy enough to soak the damage. Where as in previous games you could dodge, plan your movement and with skill avoid your enemies, now theres just too many enemies who auto- hit no matter what you do.\n\nTerrible design flaws in game play make this a 4/10 game.

reviewText:
This game is from an era when games actually posed a challenge - and where extreme difficulty truly meant extreme difficulty.
Level design is good, but can be confusing at times. Just the right amount of props and nice attention to detail.
Monster design is flawless, and impressively creative for a title of this age.
I'm not sure the physics are suitable for what the gams is about, but it sure has resulted in hysterical laughter on a few occasions.
Weapons are interesting and well balanced, and their handling feels superb.
The engine itself is a genuine masterpiece, and runs without any hickups whatsoever.


There are a few things I'm not a fan of though;
- You're forced to kill all enemies in a level, before being able to progress. Now, this wouldn't be that big of a deal, if monsters didn't sometimes hide in places they should never have been able to reach in the first place.

- The concept of soul collecting, because it forces you to wait around dead bodies for a handful of seconds, before they fizzle away and turn into souls that can be picked up.

- Coins/treasures/Tarrot cards - To this day, I still have not been able to figure out exactly what they're for.
You're fine ignoring them completely, and enjoying the game as a pure shooter anyway.

- The save/load menu is a frustrating thing to use, no matter how much experience you have with it.
The list of autosaves quickly reaches a length where maintaining an overview of your progress is impossible (just delete what you don't use at the end of each chapter).


That being said, I thoroughly enjoyed the game from beginning to end, and it managed to keep me entertained the whole time, which is a tall order these days.
The above applies to the first game of the series as well, which for some reason I cannot review.

reviewText: Painkiller, když se řekne tohle jméno, napadne vás jistě tato série her. V tomto doporučení se konkrétně budeme bavit o dílu s názvem Overdose. Takže vemu to stručně a z lehka. Nejlepší hra toto určitě není, hra se autosavuje každou takovou část" v lvlu a to každou tu část máte s větším střílecím skillem za 5 minut hotovou. Grafika je v Overdose zrovna jedna z těch lepších když se to porovná s ostatními díly (mimo H&D). Hratelnost je opět jednoduchá s nějakými podivnými prvky (jako CTRL rychlá střelba z brokovnice).\nBohužel tuto hru nemohu silně doporučit

reviewText: An astounding sequel to one of my favorite FPS. The Level design is outstanding, bringing even more variety to an already varied product. The one liners on the part of the protagonist Belial are hilarious and the new guns are beautiful. Overdose is exactly what I would have preferred out of a Painkiller sequel and Belial is definitely one of my favorite characters in the Painkiller Universe.

reviewText:
Pros:
-Enemy variety
-Unique level design, a few standouts are a demonic farm and a haunted amusement park
-New guns to play with, the new shotgun is way better

Cons:
-Lazy sound design, repeating a lot of fx from the first game, some of the editing on the airship level is very glitchy
-Developers want the lead character to be Serious Sam so badly, but he only know 4-5 one liners and constantly repeats them
-Quite short

Overall: 7/10 Worth grabbing if its on sale pretty cheap.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
What do you get when you take painkillers, chop out some parts, put some new parts in, reskin a few things in here and there and add a dash of Pop Culture References?

You get an Overdose, Painkiller: Overdose to be exact.

Released in 2007 by Czech Company Mindware Studios
date:
Overdose was originally an Expansion Pack of Painkiller, where isntead of a random dude shooting demonic forces, you play as half angel, half demon, all snarky nephilim named Belial, where he's freed from his imprisonment after thousands of years. And yet somehow, despite living in a cage, he knows movie references.

I have nary an idea, so let's move on.

If you thought the original Painkiller was tough with it's hordes of enemies and some puzzle bosses, you'll be happy to know that there's not as much enemies to deal with and puzzle bosses aren't as frequent, and much easier to work with. The core principle of PK: OD is the same.

Blast they demon asses and kill the main bad dude at the end, this time being Sammael.

Belial's got some good firepower, like the Bone Shotgun from the original game, the crossbow/bomb launcher from Battle out of Hell, the Minigun/Rocket Launcher from the first game... yeah, there's a lot of returning weapons with reskins, but there are new weapons to work with like the Demon Head you get in the beginning of the gaqme that shoots lasers, Demon Eggs that work like remote sticky bombs, A dagger that can be shot out and float in place and eviscerate enemies.

Sadly, there's no weapon that shoots shurikens and lightning, for shame. :(

Along the way, Belial will face many enemies, some new like preachers that resurrect dead foes, Ladies with propellors for arms, plus some returning foes like the kids on fire from Battle out of hell, the puppets from battle out of hell...

I'm beginning to notice a theme here... things being reused from the first Painkiller and it's expansion pack. Hell, even the theme park level is ripped from Battle out of hell, just with a different final part. Laziness is a sin.

And like in the last Painkiller, if you want to get the tarot cards, prepare to deal with some BS requirements along the way, like not picking up souls, so you can't transform into a demon. Or collecting all the souls in a level, only for an enemy to be glitched out, leaving you one soul shy. :P

However, despite all the issues, I will still heartily recommend Painkiller Overdose. It may not be the prettiest girl on the dance floor and she might have some issues, but if you have patience and are willing to see what Painkiller's like without any puzzle bosses, then give Overdose a chance. It's not much on Steam and it's pretty short.

Just be careful of chicks with propellors, they're fast and they love nephilim ♥♥♥. To carve.

reviewText: Steam doesn't record my playtime for Painkiller Black Edition, so consider this both a review of that and this expansion.\n\nAwful enemy design. Compare it to games like Serious Sam or Duke Nukem, who both had enemies that were distinctly different from each other and easily displayed what sort of attacks they had. Instead, the obsession with having unique enemies for practically every level leads to boring and indistinct variations of brown and grey spoopy thing" that often have attacks that aren't readily apparent. Also
date: most of the enemies with guns are hitscan. Combine this with level design that often borderlines on claustrophobic and you've got a game that falls flat on its face as a horde shooter.\n\nThe main game is slightly better than the expansion; some of the levels are actually nicely designed
recommended: and you aren't being peppered with the same 5 one-liners every 2 minutes
hoursPlayed: but it still suffers from the awful enemy design. If you do get any Painkiller game
voteText: get Black Edition and stop there."

reviewText:
I am going to come outright and say that this game gets Way Way too much flak. The game, while it is a worse title than the original painkiller, it still is a good game.
Pros:
I have yet to finish it, but it would seem to have a very long campaign
A fun and challenging combat system
Varied environments
And many different types of enemies to face off that each feel unique

Cons:
The game has aged quite a bit and doesn't look very good
A ♥♥♥♥ engine that has already crashed on me 3 times
Very little background music as far as I can tell
And after a while it starts getting a little repetetive.

Now this is a magnificent example of a Budget title". This game is worth what you pay for it
date: but little more. I may be treating it nice because I got it for only 50 cents
recommended: but still this is a good game. Now the biggest drawback is the fact that the music is boring as all hell. I just turned it off after the first 15 minutes. If you are going to buy this game you absolutely Must have a basic understanding of heavy metal bands or you will be bored as ♥♥♥♥ sitting on a sidewalk. So in the end I would say 6.5/10"
voteText: true

reviewText:
This game is from an era when games actually posed a challenge - and where extreme difficulty truly meant extreme difficulty.
Level design is good, but can be confusing at times. Just the right amount of props and nice attention to detail.
Monster design is flawless, and impressively creative for a title of this age.
I'm not sure the physics are suitable for what the gams is about, but it sure has resulted in hysterical laughter on a few occasions.
Weapons are interesting and well balanced, and their handling feels superb.
The engine itself is a genuine masterpiece, and runs without any hickups whatsoever.


There are a few things I'm not a fan of though;
- You're forced to kill all enemies in a level, before being able to progress. Now, this wouldn't be that big of a deal, if monsters didn't sometimes hide in places they should never have been able to reach in the first place.

- The concept of soul collecting, because it forces you to wait around dead bodies for a handful of seconds, before they fizzle away and turn into souls that can be picked up.

- Coins/treasures/Tarrot cards - To this day, I still have not been able to figure out exactly what they're for.
You're fine ignoring them completely, and enjoying the game as a pure shooter anyway.

- The save/load menu is a frustrating thing to use, no matter how much experience you have with it.
The list of autosaves quickly reaches a length where maintaining an overview of your progress is impossible (just delete what you don't use at the end of each chapter).


That being said, I thoroughly enjoyed the game from beginning to end, and it managed to keep me entertained the whole time, which is a tall order these days.
The above applies to the first game of the series as well, which for some reason I cannot review.

reviewText:
Tough game, barely made it.

I give it 7/10 if I have to rate it. Nonetheless I do recommend it.

Pros:

New monsters, new weapons, new storyline.
New character you play as.
New levels.
More killing.

Cons:

Lack of useful tarot cards, one of the reasons I barely finished the game. But I managed to get through with a few useful ones which they will help you fairly through the levels. Just hope you'll get them.

Beginning level is too much, as in it shouldnt be THAT hard for just the beginning level. To me it felt like it escalated quickly, but gets easier of course at some point, though Black Edition was not THAT hard when I played it.

The first boss was also disappointing, you'll know what I mean. You'll wonder why its not like Black Edition. But of course it will get better later through the game enough to convince you that its good enough.

Overall, great game. I also want to point out the loading is ANNOYING. But, the gameplay was fun.
